items.name: Equity Method – Investment Carrying Value
items.formula: Initial Cost + Investor's Share of Profit − Investor's Share of Dividends
items.tip: Think: I earn profit, then give out dividends

items.name: Goodwill (at Acquisition)
items.formula: Purchase Price − Fair Value of Identifiable Net Assets Acquired
items.tip: Goodwill is the extra you pay above the net worth

items.name: Basic Earnings Per Share (EPS)
items.formula: (Net Income − Preferred Dividends) ÷ Weighted-Average Common Shares Outstanding
items.mnemonic: NI minus Pref Div over Shares
items.tip: EPS = Earnings available for common shareholders

items.name: Diluted EPS
items.formula: Adjusts Basic EPS for potential conversion of dilutive securities
items.tip: What if all convertible securities were converted?

items.name: Accrual Basis vs. Cash Basis
items.formula: Accrual recognizes revenue when earned and expenses when incurred; Cash recognizes when money moves
items.tip: Accrual matches revenues and expenses; Cash counts when money moves

items.name: Revenue Recognition (5 Steps)
items.formula: Identify contract → Identify obligations → Determine price → Allocate price → Recognize revenue
items.mnemonic: I Identified Dogs And Pets Really
items.tip: 5-step model under ASC 606 / IFRS 15

items.name: Inventory Cost Flow Assumptions
items.formula: FIFO (First In First Out), LIFO (Last In First Out), Weighted Average
items.tip: In rising prices: LIFO → lower net income, lower taxes, higher cash flow

items.name: Bond Premium/Discount Amortization
items.formula: Interest Expense = Carrying Value × Market Rate
items.tip: Effective Interest Method uses the market rate at issuance, not the coupon rate

items.name: Leases (ASC 842)
items.formula: Lessee records Right-of-Use Asset and Lease Liability for all but short-term leases
items.tip: Under ASC 842, almost all leases go on the balance sheet

items.name: Statement of Cash Flows – Structure
items.formula: Operating (day-to-day) + Investing (PP&E) + Financing (debt/equity)
items.tip: Operating, Investing, Financing — the three sections of cash flows

items.name: Statement of Cash Flows – Indirect Method
items.formula: Start with NI → Add back non-cash items → Adjust for changes in working capital
items.tip: Start with NI, add back non-cash (depreciation), adjust for current assets/liabilities

items.name: External Financing Needed (EFN)
items.formula: Projected Increase in Assets − Spontaneous Increase in Liabilities − Increase in Retained Earnings
items.tip: You need money for new assets, but you get some from liabilities and retained earnings

items.name: Production Budget
items.formula: Units to Produce = Budgeted Sales + Desired Ending Inventory − Beginning Inventory
items.tip: What you need to sell plus what you want to keep, minus what you already have

items.name: Direct Materials Purchases
items.formula: Materials for Production + Desired Ending Materials − Beginning Materials
items.tip: Same structure as production budget

items.name: Learning Curve
items.formula: Y = a × X^b
items.mnemonic: Y = a times X to the b
items.tip: a = first unit cost, X = cumulative output, b = learning index. As production doubles, time per unit decreases by a constant percentage

items.name: Budgeting Process Order
items.formula: Sales → Production → Materials → Labor → Overhead
items.tip: Sales budget always comes first — everything cascades from it

items.name: Cash Budget
items.formula: Beginning Cash + Receipts − Disbursements ± Financing = Ending Cash
items.tip: Track all cash inflows and outflows to project ending balance

items.name: Pro Forma Financial Statements
items.formula: Projected financials based on assumptions and forecasts
items.tip: Used for planning and what-if analysis

items.name: Forecasting Methods
items.formula: Regression (statistical), Moving Average (smoothing), Exponential Smoothing (weighted)
items.tip: Regression is statistical; Moving Average smooths data; Exponential gives more weight to recent data

items.name: Sales Price Variance
items.formula: (Actual Price − Budgeted Price) × Actual Quantity
items.tip: Focus on price change

items.name: Direct Materials Price Variance
items.formula: (Actual Price − Standard Price) × Actual Quantity Purchased
items.tip: AP − SP = price difference

items.name: Direct Materials Usage Variance
items.formula: (Actual Quantity Used − Standard Quantity Allowed) × Standard Price
items.tip: Quantity difference × standard price

items.name: Variable Overhead Efficiency Variance
items.formula: (Actual Hours − Standard Hours) × Standard Variable Overhead Rate
items.tip: Same pattern as labor efficiency

items.name: Fixed Overhead Volume Variance
items.formula: Budgeted Fixed OH − (Standard Rate × Standard Hours Allowed)
items.tip: Volume variance = fixed overhead applied versus budgeted

items.name: Variance Analysis Pattern
items.formula: Price/Spending = (AP − SP) × AQ; Efficiency/Usage = (AQ − SQ) × SP
items.mnemonic: Price uses AQ; Efficiency uses SP
items.tip: Price variances always multiply by actual quantity; efficiency variances always multiply by standard price

items.name: Favorable vs. Unfavorable Rule
items.formula: Actual > Standard = Unfavorable; Actual < Standard = Favorable
items.mnemonic: Actual > Standard = U; Actual < Standard = F
items.tip: If you spend MORE than standard, it's unfavorable

items.name: Flexible Budget
items.formula: Budgeted per unit × Actual units produced
items.tip: Adjusts the budget for the actual activity level achieved

items.name: Responsibility Centers
items.formula: Cost center (costs), Revenue center (revenue), Profit center (costs + revenue), Investment center (profit + capital)
items.tip: Each center is evaluated on what its manager controls

items.name: Total Manufacturing Cost
items.formula: Direct Materials Used + Direct Labor + Manufacturing Overhead
items.tip: The three components of product cost

items.name: Cost of Goods Manufactured (COGM)
items.formula: Beginning WIP + Total Manufacturing Cost − Ending WIP
items.tip: What flows through production

items.name: High-Low Method
items.formula: Variable Cost per Unit = (Cost High − Cost Low) ÷ (Activity High − Activity Low)
items.tip: Change in cost over change in activity

items.name: Economic Order Quantity (EOQ)
items.tip: 2 × Demand × Order cost divided by Carrying cost, all under square root

items.name: Breakeven Point (Units)
items.formula: Total Fixed Costs ÷ Unit Contribution Margin
items.tip: How many units to cover fixed costs

items.name: Contribution Margin Ratio
items.formula: Contribution Margin ÷ Sales
items.tip: Percentage of each sales dollar that contributes to fixed costs and profit

items.name: Cost Classifications
items.formula: Direct (traceable), Indirect (not traceable), Fixed (constant total), Variable (constant per unit), Mixed (both)
items.mnemonic: Direct vs Indirect; Fixed vs Variable
items.tip: Direct costs are traceable to a cost object; indirect costs are not

items.name: Absorption vs. Variable Costing
items.formula: Absorption = all manufacturing costs as product cost; Variable = only variable manufacturing costs
items.mnemonic: Absorption includes Fixed OH; Variable excludes it
items.tip: When inventory increases, absorption income > variable income because more fixed OH is deferred

items.name: Activity-Based Costing (ABC)
items.formula: Activities consume resources; Products consume activities
items.tip: ABC assigns costs based on actual activity drivers, not volume alone

items.name: Joint Products Allocation
items.formula: Joint costs allocated based on relative sales value at split-off point
items.mnemonic: Allocate at Split-off by Sales Value
items.tip: Joint costs are common costs incurred before products become identifiable

items.name: Margin of Safety
items.formula: (Actual Sales − Breakeven Sales) ÷ Actual Sales
items.tip: How far sales can drop before you hit a loss

items.name: COSO Internal Control Framework
items.formula: Control Environment, Risk Assessment, Information & Communication, Monitoring, Existing Control Activities
items.tip: C = Control Environment, R = Risk Assessment, I = Information & Communication, M = Monitoring, E = Existing Control Activities

items.name: Control Activities
items.formula: Segregation of duties, Authorization, Physical controls, Reconciliations & reviews
items.tip: S = Segregation, A = Authorization, P = Physical controls, S = (reviews/reconciliations)

items.name: Segregation of Duties
items.formula: Custody, Authorization, Recording — no single person should do all three
items.tip: Never let one person handle Custody, Authorization, AND Recording

items.name: SOX Key Sections
items.formula: Section 302 (CEO/CFO certify financials), Section 404 (internal control assessment)
items.tip: 302 is about personal certification; 404 is about assessing and reporting on internal controls

items.name: Regression Equation
items.formula: Y = a + bX
items.tip: a = intercept (fixed cost), b = slope (variable cost per unit)

items.name: R-squared (Coefficient of Determination)
items.formula: Measures goodness of fit (0 to 1)
items.mnemonic: R² tells how well the line fits
items.tip: Closer to 1 = better fit. It's the % of variation explained by the model

items.name: Data Types
items.formula: Structured (rows/columns), Semi-structured (XML/JSON), Unstructured (emails, videos)
items.mnemonic: Structured = Tables; Semi = Tags; Unstructured = Everything else
items.tip: Most business data is unstructured; structured data fits neatly in databases

items.name: Data Mining Process (CRISP-DM)
items.formula: Business Understanding → Data Understanding → Data Preparation → Modeling → Evaluation → Deployment
items.tip: The standard methodology for data mining projects

items.name: Analytics Maturity Levels
items.formula: Descriptive (what happened), Predictive (what will happen), Prescriptive (what to do)
items.tip: Each level builds on the previous — most organizations start with descriptive

items.name: Regression Diagnostics
items.formula: R-squared (fit), p-value (significance), t-stat (individual variables)
items.mnemonic: R² = fit; p = significance; t = individual
items.tip: R² shows overall model fit; p-value tests if the model is significant; t-stat tests individual coefficients

items.name: Current Ratio
items.formula: Current Assets ÷ Current Liabilities
items.tip: Current ratio = current assets over current liabilities

items.name: Quick Ratio (Acid Test)
items.formula: (Cash + Marketable Securities + AR) ÷ Current Liabilities
items.tip: Quick assets are the most liquid: Cash, Marketable securities, Receivables

items.name: Accounts Receivable Turnover
items.formula: Net Credit Sales ÷ Average AR
items.tip: How many times we collect receivables in a year

items.name: Days Sales Outstanding
items.formula: 365 ÷ AR Turnover
items.tip: Average number of days to collect

items.name: Inventory Turnover
items.formula: COGS ÷ Average Inventory
items.tip: How many times we sell through inventory

items.name: Days Inventory Held
items.formula: 365 ÷ Inventory Turnover
items.tip: Average number of days to sell inventory

items.name: Debt to Equity Ratio
items.formula: Total Liabilities ÷ Total Equity
items.tip: Measures financial leverage

items.name: Return on Equity (ROE)
items.formula: Net Income ÷ Average Equity
items.tip: Return generated for shareholders

items.name: DuPont ROE (3-Factor)
items.formula: Net Profit Margin × Total Asset Turnover × Equity Multiplier
items.tip: The three drivers of ROE decomposed

items.name: Horizontal vs. Vertical Analysis
items.formula: Horizontal = across years (trend analysis); Vertical = within a year (common-size)
items.tip: Horizontal compares across time; Vertical expresses each item as % of a base

items.name: Liquidity Ratios Summary
items.formula: Current (CA/CL), Quick ((CA−Inv)/CL), Cash (Cash/CL)
items.tip: Each ratio removes less liquid assets to give a more conservative measure

items.name: Activity Ratios Pattern
items.formula: Turnover = Sales or COGS ÷ Average Balance; Days = 365 ÷ Turnover
items.tip: All activity ratios follow the same two-step pattern

items.name: Profitability Ratios Summary
items.formula: Profit Margin = NI/Sales; ROA = NI/Assets; ROE = NI/Equity
items.tip: Each ratio uses a different denominator to measure efficiency at different levels

items.name: Earnings Quality
items.formula: High quality = sustainable, backed by cash flows, not one-time items
items.tip: Quality earnings are repeatable and supported by actual cash generation

items.name: Limitations of Ratio Analysis
items.formula: Accounting policies, Seasonality, Industry differences, Window dressing
items.tip: Ratios are only as good as the data — watch out for these distortions

items.name: WACC
items.formula: (Wd × Kd after-tax) + (Wp × Kp) + (We × Ke)
items.tip: Weighted average of all capital components

items.name: After-Tax Cost of Debt
items.formula: Kd × (1 − Tax Rate)
items.tip: Interest is tax-deductible, so multiply by (1 − tax rate)

items.name: Cost of Equity (CAPM)
items.formula: Rf + β × (Rm − Rf)
items.tip: Risk-free rate plus beta times market risk premium

items.name: Degree of Operating Leverage (DOL)
items.formula: Contribution Margin ÷ EBIT
items.tip: How sensitive EBIT is to sales changes

items.name: Degree of Financial Leverage (DFL)
items.formula: EBIT ÷ (EBIT − Interest)
items.tip: Earnings before interest over earnings before tax

items.name: Sustainable Growth Rate
items.formula: ROE × Retention Rate
items.tip: Maximum growth without issuing new equity

items.name: Gordon Growth Model
items.formula: P₀ = D₁ ÷ (Ke − g)
items.tip: Next dividend divided by required return minus growth rate

items.name: Capital Structure Theories (MM)
items.formula: No taxes = structure irrelevant; With taxes = debt adds value via tax shield
items.mnemonic: MM: No Tax = Irrelevant; Tax = Debt Wins
items.tip: Modigliani-Miller: without taxes, capital structure doesn't matter; with taxes, debt creates a tax shield

items.name: Dividend Theories
items.formula: Irrelevance (MM), Bird-in-hand (prefer dividends), Tax preference (capital gains)
items.tip: Three views: dividends don't matter, investors prefer certainty of dividends, or investors prefer capital gains for tax reasons

items.name: Stock Splits vs. Stock Dividends
items.formula: Split = more shares, lower price; Stock dividend = transfer RE to common stock
items.mnemonic: Split = Split price; Dividend = Move RE
items.tip: Neither changes total equity — just rearranges it

items.name: Lease vs. Buy Decision
items.formula: Compare PV of lease payments vs. PV of buying costs
items.tip: Choose the option with the lower present value of total costs

items.name: Make or Buy Decision
items.formula: Compare relevant (avoidable) costs of making vs. buying
items.tip: Make if avoidable costs < purchase price; consider excess capacity

items.name: Sell or Process Further
items.formula: Process if Incremental Revenue > Incremental Cost
items.tip: Joint costs are sunk — only look at what happens AFTER the split-off point

items.name: Special Order Decision
items.formula: Accept if Incremental Revenue > Incremental Cost
items.tip: Use contribution approach — ignore allocated fixed costs. Assume excess capacity

items.name: Target Cost
items.formula: Market Price − Desired Profit
items.tip: Work backwards from the market price

items.name: Relevant Costs Rule
items.formula: Relevant costs are future, incremental, and avoidable
items.tip: Sunk costs and allocated costs are never relevant

items.name: Opportunity Cost
items.formula: The benefit foregone by choosing one alternative over another
items.tip: Always consider what you're sacrificing by choosing an option

items.name: Keep or Drop Decision
items.formula: Keep if Contribution Margin > Avoidable Fixed Costs; else drop
items.tip: Don't look at allocated costs — only avoidable costs matter

items.name: Constraint Analysis
items.formula: Maximize Contribution Margin per unit of scarce resource
items.tip: When capacity is limited, prioritize products with highest CM per bottleneck unit

items.name: Value at Risk (VaR)
items.formula: Maximum potential loss over a given time period at a given confidence level
items.tip: Think of it as a loss threshold — e.g., 95% confident loss won't exceed $X

items.name: Portfolio Expected Return
items.formula: Σ (Weight × Individual Return)
items.tip: Simple weighted sum of each asset's expected return

items.name: Types of Risk
items.formula: Market, Credit, Liquidity, Operational, Legal, Reputational
items.tip: Six major categories of enterprise risk

items.name: Risk Management Process
items.formula: Identify → Assess → Prioritize → Respond → Monitor
items.tip: The five steps of risk management — continuous cycle

items.name: Risk Response Strategies
items.formula: Avoid, Reduce, Share, Accept
items.tip: Four options when responding to identified risks

items.name: Derivatives Types
items.formula: Forwards (customized), Futures (standardized), Options (rights), Swaps (exchange)
items.tip: Forwards and Futures are obligations; Options give a right (not obligation); Swaps exchange cash flows

items.name: Net Present Value (NPV)
items.formula: Σ [CFt ÷ (1+k)^t] − Initial Investment
items.tip: If NPV > 0, accept. NPV adds value to the firm

items.name: Internal Rate of Return (IRR)
items.formula: Discount rate where NPV = 0
items.tip: Accept if IRR > hurdle rate (WACC)

items.name: Payback Period
items.formula: Initial Investment ÷ Annual Cash Flow (if even flows)
items.tip: Years to recover initial investment — ignores time value of money and cash flows after payback

items.name: Profitability Index (PI)
items.formula: PV of Future Cash Flows ÷ Initial Investment
items.tip: If PI > 1, accept. Useful for capital rationing to rank projects

items.name: After-Tax Cash Flow
items.formula: (Revenue − Cash Expenses − Depreciation) × (1 − Tax Rate) + Depreciation
items.tip: Depreciation is added back because it's a non-cash expense

items.name: Capital Budgeting Process
items.formula: Idea generation → Analysis → Selection → Implementation → Review
items.tip: The systematic process for evaluating long-term investment projects

items.name: NPV vs. IRR Conflicts
items.formula: NPV is theoretically superior; conflicts arise from reinvestment assumptions and project size differences
items.tip: NPV assumes reinvestment at WACC (realistic); IRR assumes reinvestment at IRR (often unrealistic)

items.name: Real Options
items.formula: Options to Delay, Expand, Abandon, or Contract
items.tip: Real options add strategic value beyond traditional NPV analysis

items.name: IMA Ethical Standards
items.formula: Competence, Confidentiality, Integrity, Credibility
items.tip: C = Competence, C = Confidentiality, I = Integrity, C = Credibility

items.name: IMA Ethical Principles
items.formula: Honesty, Objectivity, Fairness, Responsibility
items.tip: Principles guide behavior; Standards define specific duties

items.name: Resolution of Ethical Conflict
items.formula: Follow policies → Discuss with supervisor → Consult ethics hotline → Seek legal advice
items.tip: Always start with internal resolution before going external

items.name: Fraud Triangle
items.formula: Motivation (Pressure), Opportunity, Rationalization
items.tip: All three must exist for fraud to occur. Management can best control Opportunity through internal controls
